title: Accupril – uses, health risks, and side effects at
cleaned_text:
Accupril (Generic name: quinapril) is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. This drug is typically prescribed for treating high blood pressure and heart failure. It comes as an oral tablet.

Accupril oral tablet comes with many side effects. It may cause drowsiness. It may also cause low blood pressure, which in turn can make you feel faint or dizzy, especially if you first start taking the drug or during dosage changes. Other side effects of Accupril include headaches, dizziness, fatigue, coughing, nausea or vomiting, stomach pain, chest pain, gasping for air, diarrhea, headache, muscle pain, skin rash, and back pain. It can also cause severe side effects, such as angioedema, which causes swelling of the face, lips, tongue, and throat, difficulty breathing and swallowing, and stomach pain; high potassium levels, which causes symptoms like muscle weakness, tiredness, tingling sensations, and nausea, and; liver failure which causes yellowing of the skin or the whites of the eyes, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Accupril can also be fatal to unborn babies.

Body systems that may be harmed by Accupril

The body systems harmed by Accupril include the respiratory, nervous, digestive, integumentary, skeletal, and muscular systems.

Food items or nutrients that may prevent Accupril’s side effects

The side effects of Accupril can be prevented with the help of foods such as cherries, ginger, cranberry juice, salmon, herring, sardines, turmeric, yogurt, coffee, mint, edamame, and hot peppers.

Treatments for the side effects of Accupril, particularly low blood pressure, include the following:
• Caffeinated beverages, such as tea or coffee, may help boost your blood pressure temporarily.
• Drink at least two to three liters of water every day.
• Do not consume too much salt.
• Eat munakka to increase vitality and blood and helps in better blood circulation.
• Eat snacks or small portions several times of the day.
• Tulsi leaves, which have high levels of potassium, magnesium and vitamin C, can help in regulating your blood pressure.

Accupril is the brand name for the drug generically known as quinapril.

Accupril is prescribed for treating high blood pressure and heart failure.

Accupril also causes headaches, dizziness, fatigue, coughing, nausea or vomiting, stomach pain, chest pain, gasping for air, diarrhea, headache, muscle pain, skin rash, and back pain.

Accupril’s side effects can be prevented with foods like cherries, ginger, cranberry juice, salmon, herring, sardines, turmeric, yogurt, coffee, mint, edamame, and hot peppers.
